thread.title: De Blasio asking city councilors to delay police reform bill
thread.title_full: De Blasio asking city councilors to delay police reform bill | New York Post

author: Michael Gartland
title: De Blasio asking city councilors to delay police reform bill
text:
Fearful of a political backlash during his re-election bid, Mayor de Blasio has personally lobbied at least two City Council members to block the police-reform legislation known as the Right to Know Act, sources have told The Post.
Now comprised of two bills, the proposal’s been stuck in the council for five years without a vote.
One bill would require cops to obtain consent to conduct searches if they have no legal basis to do so. The other would require officers to provide their name, rank and precinct to people they stop.
The proposed measures put the mayor in a delicate spot because they pit the progressive wing of the council against the NYPD, with whom the mayor has had a bumpy relationship.
“He doesn’t want a war with the cops and he doesn’t want a war with the police-reform advocates,” one council member said.
Another City Hall source characterized the mayor’s recent message to the two council members as: “Please don’t do this to me. You’re putting me in a bad spot.”
Ritchie Torres Brigitte Stelzer De Blasio has weathered regular attacks from the police union over his relationship with cops, but has calmed the waters by providing significant financial support to the NYPD.
He also came to a new contract agreement with the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association, the largest police union, in January.
But that peace also opens him up to attacks from the left, which has been more vocal in recent months over the pace of police reform.
Antonio Reynoso Dennis A. Clark Last summer, de Blasio, Council Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito and then-NYPD Commissioner Bill Bratton hammered out an agreement to implement administrative changes that resemble the legislative proposals.
But reform advocates say they doesn’t go far enough.
The bills’ sponsors, Council Members Ritchie Torres (D-Bronx) and Antonio Reynoso (D-Brooklyn), have been working for months to bring the measures to the floor.
They’ve even raised the prospect of using a motion to discharge — a rarely used procedural move that would override Mark-Viverito and force the proposals to a vote.
“We’re intent on enacting the Right to Know,” Torres told The Post. “We’ve been crystal clear from the beginning that we refuse to take [a motion to] discharge off the table.”
